prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in two galaxies at z ~ 4.4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of [CII] and FIR continuum in two galaxies at z=4.44 and z=4.307. We can place the galaxies in the centers of basebands within one sideband, so we observe them together to save on overheads.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As we have two galaxies very close in redshift, we can use a single correlator setup to observe [CII] in both galaxies. The is efficient, as it avoids doing calibrations for two individual correlator set-ups, which is much more expensive. We set the central frequency of Baseband 1 in the upper sideband to 348.8 GHz, with a 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 31.25 MHz resolution. This setting will cover the frequency for [CII] for the galaxy at z=4.44. We have ensured that [CII] will fall in this baseband. We center the second baseband in the upper sideband at 349.4 GHz, which will cover [CII] from the galaxy at z=4.4307. Finally, we set the two basebands in the lower sideband at 336 and 338 GHz, to observe the far-infrared continuum. We assume the coarsest velocity resoution, as this will still yield several resolution elements per expected FWHM while maximising our sensitivity.

We do not need to spatially resolve these galaxies, which have angular sizes of ~0.5 arcsec. We set the largest angular scale to be much larger than the source size to ensure that we see [CII] even if it is spatially offset from the UV.

In this science goal, we request observations of [CII] in two galaxies at z=4.44 and z=4.307. As discussed in the science justification, we estimate the line flux by scaling from the predicted FIR luminosity based on the obscured star formation. The resulting peak line flux densities are 22.6mJy and 6.4mJy respectively. We conservatively request an rms sensitivity of 0.5 mJy based on the on-source integration time that resulted in successful detections of similar sources by Capak et al. (2015). This sensitivity will allow us to detect the line in 3-4 channels in order to resolve the dynamics. If the sources do turn out to be brighter, we will be able to increase the spectral resolution and derive a more precise dynamical mass. As the objects are very close in redshift, we elect to place them in the same science goal, using the same correlator setup, as we save significantly on calibration overheads.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in two galaxies at z~4.6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of [CII] and FIR continuum in two galaxies at z=4.6. We can place these galaxies in the center of a single basebands to save on overheads.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As we have two galaxies at the same redshift, we can use a single correlator setup to observe [CII] in both galaxies. The is efficient, as it avoids doing calibrations for two individual correlator set-ups, which is much more expensive. We set the central frequency of Baseband 1 in the lower sideband to 338.8 GHz, with a 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 31.25 MHz resolution. This setting will cover the frequency for [CII] for the galaxies at z=4.6. We have ensured that [CII] will fall in this baseband. We set the three basebands at 336.8, 349 and 350.8 GHz, to observe the far-infrared continuum. We assume the coarsest velocity resoution, as this will still yield several resolution elements per expected FWHM while maximising our sensitivity.

We do not need to spatially resolve these galaxies, which have angular sizes of ~0.5 arcsec. We set the largest angular scale to be much larger than the source size to ensure that we see [CII] even if it is spatially offset from the UV.

In this science goal, we request observations of [CII] in two galaxies at z=4.6. As discussed in the science justification, we estimate the line flux by scaling from the predicted FIR luminosity based on the obscured star formation. The resulting peak line flux densities are 15.4mJy and 8.8mJy respectively. We conservatively request an rms sensitivity of 0.5 mJy based on the on-source integration time that resulted in successful detections of similar sources by Capak et al. (2015). This sensitivity will allow us to detect the line in 3-4 channels in order to resolve the dynamics. If the sources do turn out to be brighter, we will be able to increase the spectral resolution and derive a more precise dynamical mass. As the objects are at the same redshift, we elect to place them in the same science goal, using the same correlator setup, as we save significantly on calibration overheads.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in three galaxies at z~4.7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of [CII] in three galaxies at z=4.763, 4.773 and 4.758. We can place two of the lines in one basebands and the third within the same sideband in order to save on overheads.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As we have three galaxies very close in redshift, we can use a single correlator setup to observe [CII] in both galaxies. The is efficient, as it avoids doing calibrations for two individual correlator set-ups, which is much more expensive. We set the central frequency of Baseband 3 in the upper sideband to 329.5 GHz, with a 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 31.25 MHz resolution. This setting will cover the frequency for [CII] for the galaxies at z=4.763 and z=4.758. We have ensured that [CII] will fall in this baseband. We center the second baseband in the upper sideband at 328.68 GHz, which will cover [CII] from the galaxy at z=4.773. Finally, we place basebands 1 and 2 in the lower sideband to measure FIR continuum in these sources. We assume the coarsest velocity resoution, as this will still yield several resolution elements per expected FWHM while maximising our sensitivity.

We do not need to spatially resolve these galaxies, which have angular sizes of ~0.5 arcsec. We set the largest angular scale to be much larger than the source size to ensure that we see [CII] even if it is spatially offset from the UV.

In this science goal, we request observations of [CII] in three galaxies at z=4.763, 4.773 and z=4.758. As discussed in the science justification, we estimate the line flux by scaling from the predicted FIR luminosity based on the obscured star formation. The resulting peak line flux densities are 11.6, 6.3 and 7.3mJy respectively. We conservatively request an rms sensitivity of 0.5 mJy based on the on-source integration time that resulted in successful detections of similar sources by Capak et al. (2015). This sensitivity will allow us to detect the line in 3-4 channels in order to resolve the dynamics. If the sources do turn out to be brighter, we will be able to increase the spectral resolution and derive a more precise dynamical mass. As the objects are very close in redshift, we elect to place them in the same science goal, using the same correlator setup, as we save significantly on calibration overheads.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in a galaxy at z=4.374
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of [CII] in a galaxy at z=4.374. The remaining basebands will be used to measure FIR continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We set the central frequency of Baseband 1 in the upper sideband to 353 GHz, with a 1.875 GHz bandwidth, and 31.25 MHz resolution. This setting will cover the frequency for [CII] for the galaxy at z=4.374. We have ensured that [CII] will fall in this baseband. The remaining basebands are placed at 341, 343 and 355 GHz in order to measure the FIR continuum flux.

We do not need to spatially resolve these galaxies, which have angular sizes of ~0.5 arcsec. We set the largest angular scale to be much larger than the source size to ensure that we see [CII] even if it is spatially offset from the UV.

In this science goal, we request observations of [CII] in one galaxy at z=4.374. As discussed in the science justification, we estimate the line flux by scaling from the predicted FIR luminosity based on the obscured star formation. The resulting peak line flux density is 19mJy. We conservatively request an rms sensitivity of 0.5 mJy based on the on-source integration time that resulted in successful detections of similar sources by Capak et al. (2015). If the sources do turn out to be brighter, we will be able to increase the spectral resolution and derive a more precise dynamical mass. This sensitivity will allow us to detect the line in 3-4 channels in order to resolve the dynamics.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe [CII] emission in a sample of 8 galaxies at z ~ 4.5, selected such that half of the sample exhibits Lyman alpha in emission and the other half does not. We will derive the dynamical mass from the [CII] emission line and use this with the existing stellar mass estimates to derive the gas fractions of these galaxies. With these observations, we will test whether there is a correlation between the gas mass fraction of a galaxy and the presence or absence of Lyman alpha in emission. This will enable us to address whether higher gas mass fractions in high-redshift galaxies could be responsible for at least part of the sudden decline in the fraction of galaxies with Lyman alpha detected in emission at z > 7. This has crucial implications for our understanding of galaxy evolution in the epoch of reionization. Furthermore, we will be able to constrain the L_[CII]/L_FIR relation and explore the dust properties of these galaxies, leading to crucial insight into the properties of high-redshift galaxies and informing the design of future high-redshift surveys with ALMA.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
